brief_description: Ex vivo genome editing of primary human T cells can be used to identify viral host factors
brief_title: CRISPR-Cas9 Engineering in Primary Cell Protocol
condition_studied: Ex vivo activated primary CD4+ T cells from healthy, anonymous donors
description: A detailed, peer-reviewed protocol published in Nature Protocols for optimizing CRISPR-Cas9 editing pipelines to primary cell types. A detailed example is provided for editing primary CD4+ T cells to identify HIV host factors.
endpoints: Once primary T cells are isolated from patient blood, they are activated, subjected to CRIOSPR-Cas9 genome editing, and challenged with HIV-1 to monitor replication.
hypothesis: Primary CD4+ T cells can be used as a genetically tractable system for arrayed functional genomics
objectives: Provide a detailed protocol for CRISPR-Cas9 genome engineering, primary T cell isolation, HIV preparation, and HIV spreading infection. Also, provide general tips for primary cell gene editing.
official_title: CRISPR-Cas9 Genome Engineering of Primary CD4+ T Cells for the Interrogation of HIV-host factor Interactions
sponsoring_organization: American Foundation for AIDS Research / Human Immunology Project Consortium

arm.description: optimize a high-throughput crispr knock out in primary cells
arm.name: Assay optimization

program.contract_name: Dengue Human Immunology Project Consortium (DHIPC MSSM)
